learning_outcomes.description: Recognise and explain the application of business analytics to solving practical and strategic business problems.
Understand how the principles and methods of business analytics can address business problems and improve business performance.
To create a project proposal for the design and development of a business analytics project that addresses a problem faced by business, government or society.
Apply a range of software tools for completing analytics projects and embedding analytics into decision support systems.
Assess the value of analytics projects to business and the costs and benefits of investments in analytics projects and teams.

assessments.task_description:
A one page pitch that outlines the ideation process for an analytics dashboard (web app) solution to the business problem introduced in Week 1. The industry partner will provide advice on business analytics project ideation in Week 2. The seminars in Weeks 3 through 6 will run as sprint sessions to develop the pitches, as well as instructive sessions focused on developing a deeper understanding of the business problem, data, tools for visual prototyping, and project management.

The one page pitch should focus on the main way(s) in which the project may provide value to end-users. Students should aim to maximise the interpretability of their pitch using a combination of written text and visual elements to communicate.

A full briefing of the One Page Pitch (A1) will be provided in class, covering more specific requirements of the pitch (i.e., extending what is outlined above).

Formatting Requirements:

Maximum length: 1 page

Page size: A4

Submission format: PDF (.pdf)

There is no strict word count. Students should focus on clear and concise communication, using minimal text and supporting it with visual elements (e.g., images, diagrams, graphics) to effectively convey key ideas.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT^.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

^ - Include as a text comment when submitting.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
A 10 page (approx. 3000 word) research project on the technical requirements of the proposed analytics dashboard (web app) solution to the business problem (i.e., investigating the feasibility of the ideas presented in the one page pitch). The purpose of the research project is to determine the feasibility of the solution within the constraints of the available data, software tools and personal skills. The research project should provide a detailed analysis of potential challenges and barriers to moving the solution beyond the prototype stage. These may include business-related issues, practical implementation difficulties, regulatory or compliance requirements, and any other factors that could impact deployment. The research project should include an implementation plan that outlines the steps required to develop and promote the solution as a commercialised product, including timelines and resources.

The research project should be completed concurrently alongside working on developing the technical implementation of the solution as a low-fidelity prototype or a functional deployment of an analytics dashboard (web app). The research project should include example snippets of code and screenshots of their work in progress.

A full briefing of the Research Project (A2) will be provided in class, covering more specific requirements within each section of the research project (i.e., extending what is outlined above).

Formatting Requirements:

Word count: 3,000 words (+/- 300 words, excludes text in tables, figures, title page, table of contents, headings, headers, footers and references)

Page count: 10 pages (maximum)

Page size: A4

Submission format: PDF (.pdf), Word Doc (.docx), or HTML (.html)

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT^.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

^ - Include as a text comment when submitting.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
An in-person 5-minute demonstration of a low-fidelity prototype or a functional deployment of an analytics dashboard (web app) solution to the business problem, i.e., the technical implementation of the ideas initially proposed in the One Page pitch (A1) and refined in the Research Project (A2).

The demonstration should showcase the apps main features, overall structure, and user experience. It should illustrate how the application enables users to derive data-driven insights that effectively address the business problem in a technically sound and creative way. A detailed technical explanation of the underlying code is not required.

A full briefing of the Technical Demonstration (A3) will be provided in class, covering more specific requirements of the demonstration (i.e., extending what is outlined above).

Formatting Requirements:

Length: 5 minutes

Format: Verbal explanation supported by on-screen interaction with the app. Accompanying slides or pre-recorded content are not permitted.

Students demonstrate their app via the in-class projector (using either their own laptop or the in-class computer).

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT^.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

^ - Include as a text comment when submitting.

assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction & Problem Framing

Introduction to the course project and a business problem which will form the basis for their business analytics project. Students explore the problem space, stakeholders, and rationale for applying business analytics to real-world decision-making. Students are introduced to the responsible use of AI tools to support exploration, idea generation, and problem framing.

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction & Problem Framing Introduction to the course project and a business problem which will form the basis for their business analytics project. Students explore the problem space, stakeholders, and rationale for applying business analytics to real-world decision-making. Students are introduced to the responsible use of AI tools to support exploration, idea generation, and problem framing.

learning_activities.topic:
Industry Engagement 1: Project Discovery

Session with the industry partner to discuss how analytics projects typically begin, including ideation, problem framing, discovery activities, and early decision-making.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Industry Engagement 1: Project Discovery Session with the industry partner to discuss how analytics projects typically begin, including ideation, problem framing, discovery activities, and early decision-making.

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 1: Exploration and Insight Generation

Students explore a project dataset (supplied) using appropriate analytical tools to examine data structure and patterns, surface potential insights, and begin developing a narrative grounded in user needs in the context of the business problem discussed in Week 1. AI can be used to help formulate the approach to highlighting patterns in the data and to explain unfamiliar data structures.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 1: Exploration and Insight Generation Students explore a project dataset (supplied) using appropriate analytical tools to examine data structure and patterns, surface potential insights, and begin developing a narrative grounded in user needs in the context of the business problem discussed in Week 1. AI can be used to help formulate the approach to highlighting patterns in the data and to explain unfamiliar data structures.

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 2: Concept Design and Prototyping

Introduction to low fidelity prototyping methods. Students translate insights and user needs into initial requirements, and design and communicate application concepts and user flows prior to technical implementation. AI can support idea generation, requirement articulation, and early prototyping concepts, while students maintain ownership of design decisions.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 2: Concept Design and Prototyping Introduction to low fidelity prototyping methods. Students translate insights and user needs into initial requirements, and design and communicate application concepts and user flows prior to technical implementation. AI can support idea generation, requirement articulation, and early prototyping concepts, while students maintain ownership of design decisions.

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 3: User Experience and Value Proposition

Focus on shaping analytics outputs that are intuitive and meaningful for end-users, and that clearly communicate value in a decision-making context.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Sprint Session 3: User Experience and Value Proposition
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 3: User Experience and Value Proposition Focus on shaping analytics outputs that are intuitive and meaningful for end-users, and that clearly communicate value in a decision-making context.

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 4: Validation and Feedback

Peer review and testing of early concepts or prototypes. Students evaluate logic, clarity, and alignment with user needs.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 4: Validation and Feedback Peer review and testing of early concepts or prototypes. Students evaluate logic, clarity, and alignment with user needs.
Midsemester Break No class this week

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 5: Refinement and Planning

Reflection on assessment feedback and project direction. Students prioritise features, refine scope, and plan the next phase of development.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 5: Refinement and Planning Reflection on assessment feedback and project direction. Students prioritise features, refine scope, and plan the next phase of development.

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 6: Technical Feasibility and Implementation Planning

Exploration of technical options and constraints. Students research tools, libraries, or integrations and assess feasibility of proposed features. AI can support code exploration, package research, and troubleshooting strategies, while students critically evaluate all outputs.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Sprint Session 6: Technical Feasibility and Implementation Planning
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 6: Technical Feasibility and Implementation Planning Exploration of technical options and constraints. Students research tools, libraries, or integrations and assess feasibility of proposed features. AI can support code exploration, package research, and troubleshooting strategies, while students critically evaluate all outputs.

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 7: Build and Integration

Development and integration of analytical components into the application. Students connect analysis, design, and functionality, and document limitations and future considerations. AI can assist with coding suggestions, debugging, and documentation, but ownership and validation remain with the student.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 7: Build and Integration Development and integration of analytical components into the application. Students connect analysis, design, and functionality, and document limitations and future considerations. AI can assist with coding suggestions, debugging, and documentation, but ownership and validation remain with the student.

No class

learning_activities.topic:
Sprint Session 8: Deployment and Testing

Application deployment and troubleshooting. Focus on handling edge cases, refining presentation, and reflecting on development decisions and trade-offs.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Sprint Session 8: Deployment and Testing Application deployment and troubleshooting. Focus on handling edge cases, refining presentation, and reflecting on development decisions and trade-offs.

learning_activities.topic:
Technical Demonstrations (A3) - Session 1

In-class technical demonstrations of a low-fidelity prototype or a functional deployment of an analytics dashboard (web app) solution to the business problem. Students present their app to the class showcasing its functionality, analytical approach, and design rationale.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Technical Demonstrations (A3) - Session 1 In-class technical demonstrations of a low-fidelity prototype or a functional deployment of an analytics dashboard (web app) solution to the business problem. Students present their app to the class showcasing its functionality, analytical approach, and design rationale.

learning_activities.topic:
Technical Demonstrations (A3) - Session 2

Continuation of in-class technical demonstrations.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Technical Demonstrations (A3) - Session 2 Continuation of in-class technical demonstrations.
